text: <@U030GKBMCBF> Yes you can get anything that's on the Timeform website, including declarations and results going back years including the stuff you get with their subscription like timefigures, ratings, premium comments etc. It's not as easy to scrape as the racing post. And it takes A LOT longer because you get rate limited

text: I'm happy to be educated by someone like <@U012XF5CNPN> but my understanding is a book is the set of prices you're showing (I.e. taking bets at), _not_ your set of fair odds. In which case your "book price" is the price with your margin built in and how you apply that margin is a critical component of making a book

text: What is meant by “showing”

text: ??? A bookmaker has a book: it's the set of prices they are showing/offering/taking bets on/displaying to their customers/advertising/I don't know how else to put. The exchange has a book: it's the set of current available prices

elements.text: ??? A bookmaker has a book: it's the set of prices they are showing/offering/taking bets on/displaying to their customers/advertising/I don't know how else to put. The exchange has a book: it's the set of current available prices

text: <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> Think of it as if you were going to LAY all runners in a horse race pre-off. Imagine the market starts empty and you are first in - how are you going to decide the prices to offer and how much money to make available for each. That is what "making a book" is in a very very simplified manner

elements.text: Think of it as if you were going to LAY all runners in a horse race pre-off. That is what "making a book" is in a very very simplified manner

text: Go to Hills or Laddies - and calculate the overround on the prices they are "showing" . Then compare the same with Betfair 60 seconds before the off.

elements.text: Go to Hills or Laddies - and calculate the overround on the prices they are "showing" . Then compare the same with Betfair 60 seconds before the off.

text: If you don't know what overround or margin is, I suggest maybe starting off with one of Joseph Buchdahl's early books

yeah I understand overround, eg.sum of back odds being 105% on exchange, and no doubt Hill's overround would be nearer 110%

text: yeah I get confused when people say "make your own book" ... which I think I understand is actually trying to match selections in a race to say get a 120% book, rather than trying to workout "fair price"

elements.text: yeah I get confused when people say "make your own book" ... which I think I understand is actually trying to match selections in a race to say get a 120% book, rather than trying to workout "fair price"

text: In crude terms, if you were modelling, you'd get outcome probabilities, calculate "fair" price, then make them more shit (to the punter) by applying margin to those prices (making them shorter). How you spread the margin across the runners though is down to the bookie - and they may (or may not) adjust prices based on weight of punter money. Genuinely sounds like you could do with reading a basic book on betting <@U01PJ5YMFBJ> to get a firmer grip of this stuff. It may not be necessary but you'll get a more detailed explanation of things.

elements.text: In crude terms, if you were modelling, you'd get outcome probabilities, calculate "fair" price, then make them more shit (to the punter) by applying margin to those prices (making them shorter). text: In my last job I was reading "Fixed Odds Sports Betting" by Buchdahl when I had to get involved with applying and removing margins - it definitely had a section on that stuff somewhere. Probably any basic book on sports betting will do although some of them use more American terms (and odds format which I hate) which can be confusing.
